SPEC

Society Promoting Environmental Conservation (SPEC)
is a non-profit organization in Vancouver, British Columbia. Their mission is to provide the community with practical solutions for urban sustainability.

Challenges

SPEC relies on a revolving door of talented volunteers to maintain their website. For this reason, the website had difficulty maintaining a level of quality and consistency my client would prefer. Some challenges include:

  • Decentralized integrations such as multiple blogs, mail distribution and payment systems having a negative impact on user experience.
  • Use of a legacy template with non-responsive styling.
  • Site content and assets have not been reviewed or organized.
  • Site is built with Wild Apricot — a CMS which is lacks versatility in customization.

Goal

Create a site that is visually appealing, navigable, responsive and user-friendly to attract volunteers and donors to the site.

Solutions

Define Scope

The client and I narrowed down the priorities.

  1. Organize site by creating new site map and removing unnecessary content.
  2. Create wireframes and prototypes.
  3. Develop new templates and styling based on agreed prototype.

Competitive Analysis

We looked at other local non-profits (Georgia Strait Alliance, Surf Riders, David Suzuki Foundation) for inspiration and discussing the motivations of the client, we were able to distill the needs of the existing SPEC site and start narrowing down the sites core content and merge or eliminate dozens of pages and links.

Gathering existing assets developed by volunteers was beneficial, an existing graphic standards manual had previously been developed. This helped move the design work forward by adhering to the standards that made sense for the web. At the same time, it is always good to challenge the standards that seemed relevant at the time and require some updating.

Information Architecture

Simplifying the navigation to help users find things easily was crucial to the success of the redesign. Action taken:

  1. Consolidated similar pages.
  2. Shortened navigation link names to more readable and quicly understandable names.
  3. Archived, purged or rewrote content.
  4. Reorder navigation by assumed typical user journey.

Wireframe

Prototype

CMS Administration

Creating custom templates in Wild Apricot required a bit of trial & error, reading documentation, and watching tutorials. Lesson learned: Always start with fresh template so old template content does not start acting like layout goblins. After setting up a test account, I was able to explore the templates that aligned best with the prototypes.

Coding

There are options to overwrite the styling through a GUI with set parameters or in a separate stylesheet. Understanding how things are put together under the hood and targeting the proper elements required a lot of tinkering and page reloads.

Results

The goals we targeted have been achieved and value has been added to this website:

  • A more visually appealing website has been created with consistency across all visual elements.
  • The site is now responsive and user-friendly for mobile, tablet and desktop devices.
  • Navigation has been simplified and made more intuitive after reorganizing, recategorizing, rewriting, purging and renaming content.

The client received complements from his colleagues and site visitors on the overall improvement of the site. Measuring site traffic and membership numbers are some KPIs that will show if the changes has made a positive impact.
